title: Washington, D.C., Police Fight a Rise in Carjackings and Blame Covid-19
sub_head: Nation’s capital, other cities report sharp increases in carjackings in 2020
body:
During the pandemic, police officers in Washington, D.C., started noticing a rise in a crime that alarmed them: teenagers forcibly stealing occupied cars and often going for joy rides.
Police departments in cities around the country are also reporting rises in carjackings, often committed by teens too young for their licenses.
This month, Washington, D.C.’s Metropolitan Police Department launched a carjacking task force, along with federal law-enforcement officials, the district’s juvenile justice agency and police in nearby Maryland counties.
Law-enforcement officials blame the rise on a host of factors, including the switch to virtual schooling, the growing ranks of delivery drivers who are often targeted and less legal accountability due to pandemic-related delays and disruptions in the criminal justice system. Overall crime in Washington fell 19% in 2020 compared with the previous year, while carjackings jumped 143%, police department statistics show.
A department spokeswoman said the pandemic has given youths fewer opportunities overall to commit crime. Juvenile arrests in Washington dropped by 44% from 2019.
